newsitem.title: USA: NYMEX natgas ends up, shorts cover on firmer cash.
newsitem.headline: NYMEX natgas ends up, shorts cover on firmer cash.

text.p: NYMEX Henry Hub natgas futures ended higher across the board Tuesday in a moderate session, lifted by a steady stream of short covering amid unexpected strength in the cash, industry sources said.
April rallied 14 cents to close at $1.943 per million British thermal units. May settled 11.6 cents higher at $1.979. Other deferreds ended up by 4.2 to 9.4 cents.

"This was a constructive settlement. We couldn't get below $1.80 (in April) with any conviction, then we broke a steep downtrend. Everyone was betting on the short side and got caught," said one Midwest trader, adding April could break $2.
Traders said reports of firmer physical prices from injection buying in the producing region spilled into the paper market, stampeding the shorts.
But while some felt the seasonal bottom was in place, most still expected the upside to be limited by forecasts for milder weather later in the week.

Technical traders said April's close above resistance at $1.93 should lead to a test of the $2.04 area. Support was still seen at $1.78-80, with further buying likely in the mid-$1.70s and then at the contract low of $1.701.

In the physical market, Gulf Coast prices gained almost 10 cents Tuesday to the mid-$1.80s. Midcon pipes were more than five cents higher in the low-$1.70s. New York city gate swing gas eased several cents to about $2.10.
NYMEX Permian and Alberta natgas did not trade Tuesday.

On the KCBT, April finished 13 cents higher at $1.71, while deferreds ended up by six to 12 cents. The East/West spread widened by one cent to 23.3 cents (NYMEX premium). KCBT said 412 lots changed hands, up from Monday's total of 187.
